content.question:
For parts of the free response question that require calculations, clearly show the method used and the steps involved in arriving at your answers. You must show your work to receive credit for your answer. Examples and equations may be included in your answers where appropriate.

Dry air is comprised of <math alttext="N 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">N</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math>, <math alttext="O 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math>, and traces of other gases.

A student obtains a <math alttext="2.00 liter" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2.00</mn><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mi mathvariant="normal">L</mi></math> container filled with a sample of dry air at a total pressure of <math alttext="1.30 atmospheres" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1.30</mn><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mi>atm</mi></math> and a temperature of <math alttext="295 kelvin" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>295</mn><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mi mathvariant="normal">K</mi></math>.

(a) Calculate the total number of moles of gas in the container.

frqParts.text:
For parts of the free response question that require calculations, clearly show the method used and the steps involved in arriving at your answers. You must show your work to receive credit for your answer. Examples and equations may be included in your answers where appropriate.

Dry air is comprised of <math alttext="N 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">N</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math>, <math alttext="O 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math>, and traces of other gases.

A student obtains a <math alttext="2.00 liter" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2.00</mn><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mi mathvariant="normal">L</mi></math> container filled with a sample of dry air at a total pressure of <math alttext="1.30 atmospheres" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1.30</mn><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mi>atm</mi></math> and a temperature of <math alttext="295 kelvin" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>295</mn><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mi mathvariant="normal">K</mi></math>.

(a) Calculate the total number of moles of gas in the container.

(b) The student cools the gaseous mixture until either <math alttext="N 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">N</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math> or <math alttext="O 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math> condenses. Which gas will condense first? Justify your answer in terms of the types and relative strengths of the intermolecular forces in <math alttext="N 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">N</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math> and <math alttext="O 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math>.

(c) Using the legend given, draw at least three molecules of each type of gas in the sealed container represented below when one of the substances has condensed, but the other substance is still a gas.

(d) In this sample, <math alttext="78%" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>78</mn><mo>%</mo></math> of the molecules are <math alttext="N 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">N</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math> and <math alttext="21%" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>21</mn><mo>%</mo></math> of the molecules are <math alttext="O 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math>. Calculate the total number of grams of the substance that condenses first.

skill.text: 3.C: Represent visually the relationship between the structures and interactions across multiple levels or scales (e.g., particulate to macroscopic).
